page.title: List of international presidential trips made by Abdullah Gül

revision.comment: Moving from [[Category:Diplomatic visits by heads of state]] to [[Category:Lists of diplomatic visits by heads of state]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
[[File:Gül and Napolitano.jpg|thumb|President Gul and Italian President [[Giorgio Napolitano]] during the official state visit at [[Quirinal Palace]], 29 January 2014]] This is a '''list of presidential trips made by [[Abdullah Gül]]''', the [[List of Presidents of Turkey|11th]] [[President of Turkey|President of Republic of Turkey]]. During his presidency, which began with his [[Turkish presidential election, 2007|inauguration on August 28, 2007]], Abdullah Gül has travelled to 63 different states internationally as of February 2014. ==Summary of international trips== [[File:Abdullah Gül foreign trips.png|thumb|center|500px|Map of international trips made by Abdullah Gül as president]] {| class=wikitable |- !Number of visits !Country |- |1 visit |Albania, Armenia, Bahrain, Bangladesh, Belgium, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Cameroon, China, Croatia, [[DR Congo]], Estonia, Finland, Gabon, Georgia, Ghana, Hungary, India, Indonesia, Iraq, Italy, Japan, Jordan, Kenya, Latvia, Lithuania, Macedonia, Montenegro, Netherlands, Nigeria, Oman, Poland, Portugal, Qatar, Senegal, Slovakia, Slovenia, South Korea, Sweden, Tajikistan, Tanzania, Tunisia, United Arab Emirates, Yemen |- |2 visits |Austria, Bulgaria, Czech Republic, Iran, Kuwait, Kyrgyzstan, Northern Cyprus, Pakistan, Romania, Russia, Serbia, Switzerland, Syria, United Kingdom |- |3 visits |Germany |- |4 visits |Saudi Arabia, Turkmenistan, United States |- |5 visits |Azerbaijan, France, Kazakhstan |- |6 visits |Egypt |} ==2007== The following international trips were made by Abdullah Gül during 2007: {| class="wikitable outercollapse" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- ! width=120|Country ! width=100|Areas visited !width=90|Date(s) ! width=550|Notes |- |Northern Cyprus |[[North Nicosia]] |September 18 |{{See also|Embassy of Turkey to the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus}} [[State visit]] {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- | Abdullah Gül made his first visit abroad to the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus as president. Gül met with [[President of Northern Cyprus|President]] [[Mehmet Ali Talat]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49836/turkish-republic-of-northern-cyprus.html|title=Foreign visits:Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=2007-09-18|accessdate=2014-02-27}} |} |- |France |[[Strasbourg]] |October 2–4 |{{See also|Accession of Turkey to the European Union}} {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |President Abdullah Gül addressed the [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe]]. Gül met with President [[René van der Linden]] and senior officials{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49837/france.html|title=Foreign visits:France|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=02-10-2007|accessdate=2014-02-27}} |} |- |Azerbaijan |[[Baku]] |November 6 |{{See also|Azerbaijan–Turkey relations}} [[State visit]] {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |President Abdullah Gül and his wife [[Hayrünnisa Gül]] made a state visit to Azerbaijan. In this context, Gül met with [[President of Azerbaijan|President]] [[Ilham Aliyev]] and [[Prime Minister of Azerbaijan|Prime Minister]] [[Artur Rasizade]]. Also he delivered a speech to the [[National Assembly (Azerbaijan)|National Assembly of Azerbaijan]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49838/azerbaijan.html|title=Foreign visits: Azerbaijan|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=06-11-2007|accessdate=2014-02-27}} |} |- |Georgia |[[Tbilisi]] |November 20–21 |{{See also|Georgia–Turkey relations}} {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |President Gül was attending with Azerbaijani President [[İlham Aliyev]] foundation laying ceremony for the [[Kars–Tbilisi–Baku railway]] line and before, met with Georgian President [[Mikheil Saakashvili]] in [[Tbilisi]]{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49839/georgia.html|title=Foreign visits: Georgia|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=2007-11-20|accessdate=2014-02-27}} |} |- |France |[[Paris]] |November 25 |{{See also|France–Turkey relations}} {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |Abdullah Gül addressed the [[Bureau of International Expositions|General Assembly of the International Exhibitions Bureau]] (BIE) to promote the candidacy of [[İzmir]] for [[Expo 2015]].{{Cite news|first= |last= |title=Gül to visit France for İzmir EXPO 2015 bid|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/default.aspx?pageid=438&n=gul-to-visit-france-for-izmir-expo-2015-bid-2007-11-24|publisher=[[Hürriyet Daily News]]|date=November 24, 2007 |accessdate=February 27, 2014}} |} |- |Pakistan |[[Islamabad]] |December 2–3 |{{See also|Pakistan–Turkey relations}} [[State visit]] {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |President Abdullah Gül paid an official visit to Pakistan, with the invitation of the [[President of Pakistan|President]] of the Pakistan, [[Pervez Musharraf]]. Also, Mr. Gül received leading Pakistani politicians including [[Benazir Bhutto]] and [[Nawaz Sharif]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49841/pakistan.html|title=Foreign visits: Pakistan|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=02-12-2007|accessdate=2014-02-27}} |} |- |Turkmenistan |[[Ashgabat]] |December 5–7 | [[State visit]] {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |President Abdullah Gül made a state visit to Turkmenistan. Gül met with counterpart [[Gurbanguly Berdimuhamedow]] and Turkish citizens and businessmen living in [[Ashgabat]]{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49842/turkmenistan.html|title=Foreign visits: Turkmenisatn|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=05-12-2007|accessdate=2014-02-27}} |} |- |Kazakhstan |[[Astana]], [[Almaty]] |December 12–15 |{{See also|Kazakhstan–Turkey relations}} [[State visit]] {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |President Gül met with [[President of Kazakhstan|President]] [[Nursultan Nazarbayev]]. He was attended celebrating Kazakhstan's independence day and toured around a selection of facilities and organizations run by Turkish entrepreneurs in [[Almaty]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49843/kazakhstan.html|title=Foreign visits: Kazakhstan|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=2007-12-12|accessdate=2014-02-27}} |} |} ==2008== The following international trips were made by Abdullah Gül during 2008: {| class="wikitable outercollapse" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- ! width=120|Country ! width=100|Areas visited !width=90|Date(s) ! width=550|Notes |- |United States |[[Washington, D.C.]]
[[New York City]] |January 7–11 |{{See also|Turkey–United States relations}} [[State visit]] {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |President Gül made an official visit to the United States at the invitation of [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[George W. Bush]] and he held talks with American press, non-governmental organizations and [[Turkish American|Turkish community]] in the [[Washington, D.C.]] and [[New York City]]{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49844/united-states-of-america.html|title=Foreign visits: United States of America|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=07-01-2008|accessdate=2014-02-28}}{{Cite news|first= |last= |title=Turkish President Abdullah Gul to Visit White House|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/2007/12/28/turkish-president-abdullah-gul-to-visit-white-house/|publisher=[[Fox News]]|date=December 28, 2007 |accessdate=February 28, 2014}} |} |- |Egypt |[[Cairo]], [[Alexandria]] |January 14–16 |{{See also|Egypt–Turkey relations}} [[State visit]] {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |Gul made official a trip to Egypt at the invitation of [[President of Egypt|President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]]. Furthermore, Abdullah Gül made a speech at the Turkish-Egyptian Business Forum and visited [[Bibliotheca Alexandrina]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49845/egypt.html|title=Foreign visits: Egypt|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=2008-01-14|accessdate=2014-02-28}} |} |- |Syria |[[Damascus]] |January 19 |{{See also|Syria–Turkey relations}} {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |President Abdullah Gül paid a one-day visit to Syria for [[Damascus]] [[Arab Capital of Culture]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49846/syria.html|title=Foreign visits: Syria|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=2008-01-19|accessdate=2014-02-28}} |} |- |Qatar |[[Doha]] |February 5–7 |{{See also|Qatar–Turkey relations}} [[State visit]] {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |Abdullah Gül paid an official visit to Qatar with the invitation of the [[List of emirs of Qatar|Emir of the Qatar]], [[Hamad bin Khalifa Al Thani]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49847/qatar.html|title=Foreign visits: Qatar|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=05-02-2008|accessdate=2014-02-28}} |} |- |Romania |[[Bucharest]] |March 2–4 |{{See also|Romania–Turkey relations}} [[State visit]] {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |President Gül made an official state visit to the Romania at the invitation of [[President of Romania|President]] [[Traian Băsescu]]. Mr. Gül talks held with President Basescu as well as he received Prime Minister, Chairmans of the Parliament and Senate. Also, Gul was awarded with an honorary doctorate by [[Dimitrie Cantemir Christian University]] in [[Bucharest]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49848/romania.html|title=Foreign visits: Romania|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=02-03-2008|accessdate=2014-02-28}} |} |- |Senegal |[[Dakar]] |March 13–14 |{{See also|Organisation of Islamic Cooperation}} {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |President Gül attended the 11th Summit meeting of the [[Organization of the Islamic Cooperation]] (OIC) in [[Dakar]], Senegal.{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49851/senegal.html|title=Foreign visits: Senegal|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=2008-03-13|accessdate=2014-02-28}} |} |- |France |[[Paris]] |March 31 |{{See also|France–Turkey relations}} '''[[Expo 2015]]''' {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |President Gül visited to [[Paris]] to give support to the candidate city of [[İzmir]]{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49852/france.html|title=Foreign visits: France|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=2008-03-31|accessdate=2014-02-28}} |} |- |Romania |[[Bucharest]] |April 2–4 |{{See also|Romania–Turkey relations}} '''[[2008 Bucharest summit|NATO summit]]''' {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |President Abdullah Gül traveled to Bucharest, Romania to attend the [[2008 Bucharest summit]] of [[NATO]]. Gül met with President [[Traian Băsescu]]. The President later attended a meeting of the North Atlantic Council, meeting with [[heads of government]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49853/romania.html|title=Foreign visits: Romania|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=02-04-2008|accessdate=2014-03-02}} |} |- |Macedonia |[[Skopje]], [[Ohrid]] |May 1–3 |{{See also|Macedonia–Turkey relations}} '''[[Ohrid Summit 2008]]''' {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |President Gül traveled to Republic of Macedonia to attend as the guest of honour the [[Ohrid Summit 2008|15th Summit]] meeting of the presidents of [[Central Europe]]an States in city of [[Ohrid]]. Mr. Gül met with President [[Branko Crvenkovski]] and other counterparts.{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49854/macedonia.html|title=Foreign visits: Macedonia|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=01-05-2008|accessdate=2014-03-02}} |} |- |Japan |[[Tokyo]], [[Kushimoto, Wakayama|Kushimoto]] |June 3–8 |{{See also|Japan–Turkey relations}} [[State visit]] {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |Since the 1924 establishment of diplomatic relations between Turkey and Japan, for the first time a Turkish President visited to Japan. President Abdullah Gül and his wife [[Hayrünnisa Gül]] paid an official visit to Japan at the invitation of Imperial Majesty [[Emperor of Japan|Emperor]] [[Akihito]]. Gül and Mrs. Gül met with Emperor [[Akihito]] and [[Empress Michiko]] at [[Tokyo Imperial Palace|Imperial Palace]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49855/japan.html|title=Foreign visits: Japan|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=03-06-2008|accessdate=2014-03-02}} |} |- |Croatia |[[Zagreb]], [[Dubrovnik]] |June 10–12 |{{See also|Croatia–Turkey relations}} [[State visit]] {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |President Gül and his wife Mrs. Gül made an official state visit to the Croatia at the invitation of [[President of Croatia|Croatian President]] [[Stjepan Mesić]].Two presidents discussed the developments in their bilateral relations as well as regional and international issues.After the meeting, [[Abdullah Gül]] and Mrs. Gül travelled to Croatia's historic city of [[Dubrovnik]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49856/croatia.html|title=Foreign visits: Croatia|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=10-06-2008|accessdate=2014-03-02}} |} |- |Kazakhstan |[[Astana]] |July 4–6 |{{See also|Kazakhstan–Turkey relations}} {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |President Gül traveled to [[Astana]], Kazakhstan, to attend the 10th anniversary ceremonies of the Kazakh capital city of Astana. During his visit, Gül met with Kazakh leader [[Nursultan Nazarbayev]] and other participant presidents.{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49857/kazakhstan.html|title=Foreign visits: Kazakhstan|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=04-07-2008|accessdate=2014-03-02}} |} |- |Armenia |[[Yerevan]] |September 6 |{{See also|Armenia–Turkey relations}} {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |President Abdullah Gül visited Armenia at the invitation of the [[Armenian President]] [[Serzh Sargsyan]] to watch a [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification – UEFA Group 5|World Cup qualifying]] match between the national teams of the two countries.Gül and Sargsyan discussed the bilateral relations and ongoing dispute Nagorno-Karabakh at the Presidential Palace. Then, two leaders watched the match which Turkey beat Armenia [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification – UEFA Group 5#Armenia v Turkey|2-0]] in [[Hrazdan Stadium]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49858/armenia.html|title=Foreign visits: Armenia|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=06-09-2008|accessdate=2014-03-08}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/07/world/europe/07turkey.html|title=Turkey's President Makes Historic Visit to Armenia|publisher=[[New York Times]]|date=06-09-2008|accessdate=2014-03-08}} |} |- |Azerbaijan |[[Baku]] |September 10 |{{See also|Azerbaijan–Turkey relations}} {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |President Gül visited to [[Baku]] for one-day working visit. Mr. Gül and Azerbaijani President [[İlham Aliyev]] discussed their bilateral and [[Special relationship (international relations)|special relations]]. Following a joint press conference, President Aliyev, gave dinner in honor of [[Abdullah Gül]] at the Presidential Palace.{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49865/azerbaijan.html|title=Foreign visits: Azerbaijan 2|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=10-09-2008|accessdate=2014-03-02}} |} |- |United States |[[New York City]] |September 20–29 |{{See also|Turkey-United States relations}} {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |President Abdullah Gül travalled to United States to attend the 63rd Session of the [[United Nations General Assembly]]. Gül made a speech at the opening session of the UN General Assembly on 23 September and met with representatives of the Turkish Society and [[Meskhetian Turks]]. During his programme in New York, Mr. Gül had numerous bilateral meetings with heads of state and government attending the UN General Assembly{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49866/united-states-of-america.html|title=Foreign visits: United States|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=2008-09-20|accessdate=2014-03-10}} |} |- |Finland |[[Helsinki]], [[Jyväskylä]] |October 7–9 |{{See also|Finland–Turkey relations}} [[State visit]] {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |President Gül and his wife made official state visit to Finland at the invitation of [[President of Finland|Finnish President]] [[Tarja Halonen]]. Abdullah Gül met with counterpart Halonen and received Finnish Parliament [[Sauli Niinistö]] and Prime Minister [[Matti Vanhanen]]. He then flew to city of [[Jyväskylä]] and visited Alvar Aalto Museum and Jyväskylä University. Also he attended the [[Martti Ahtisaari]] Conference here.{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49867/finland.html|title=Foreign visits: Finland|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=07-10-2008|accessdate=2014-03-10}} |} |- |Estonia |[[Tallinn]] |October 9–11 | [[State visit]] {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |President Gül and his wife Mrs. Gül made an official state visit to the Estonia at the invitation of [[President of Estonia|Estonian President]] [[Toomas Hendrik Ilves]]. Mr. Gül attended a meeting of the Turkish-Estonian Business Council at the [[Estonian Chamber of Commerce and Industry]]. Gul met with President Ilves and Prime Minister [[Andrus Ansip]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49870/estonia.html|title=Foreign visits: Estonia|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=09-10-2008|accessdate=2014-03-10}} |} |- |Germany |[[Frankfurt]] |October 14–15 |{{See also|Germany–Turkey relations}} {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |President Gül and his wife [[Hayrünnisa Gül]] travalled to [[Frankfurt]] to attend as guest of honor 60th [[Frankfurt Book Fair]]. Gül and his wife visited the Frankfurt Town Hall and signed the city's Golden Book. During his visit, Mr. Gül met with German President [[Horst Köhler]] and Foreign Minister [[Frank-Walter Steinmeier]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/yurt-disi/254/49581/almanya.html|title=Foreign visits: Almanya/Germany|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=2008-10-14|accessdate=2014-03-10}} |} |- |Azerbaijan |[[Baku]] |November 13–14 |{{See also|Azerbaijan–Turkey relations}} {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |President Gül travelled to Azerbaijan to attend the Energy Summit held in [[Baku]]. Mr. Gül met with Azerbaijani President [[Ilham Aliyev]] at the Presidential Palace. Furthermore, Gül talks with other participant presidents and opened a new annex for the Baku Anatolian High School.{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49872/azerbaijan.html|title=Foreign visits: Azerbaijan 3|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=2008-11-13|accessdate=2014-03-10}} |} |- |Turkmenistan |[[Ashgabat]], [[Türkmenbaşy, Turkmenistan|Türkmenbaşy]] |November 28–29 | {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |President [[Abdullah Gül]] paid a working visit to Turkmenistan at the invitation of [[President of Turkmenistan|Turkmen President]] [[Gurbanguly Berdimuhamedow]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49877/turkmenistan.html|title=Foreign visits: Turkmenistan 2|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=2008-11-28|accessdate=2014-03-10}} |} |} ==2009== The following international trips were made by Abdullah Gül during 2009: {| class="wikitable outercollapse" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- ! width=120|Country ! width=100|Areas visited !width=90|Date(s) ! width=550|Notes |- |Egypt |[[Sharm el-Sheikh]] |January 18 |{{See also|Egypt–Turkey relations}} {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |President Abdullah Gül attend discussed the issue of [[Gaza Strip|Gaza]] in Egypt. Mr.Gül met with Egyptian President [[Hosni Mubarak]], French President [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] and German Chancellor [[Angela Merkel]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49878/egypt.html|title=Foreign visits: Egypt|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=08-01-2009|accessdate=2014-03-15}} |} |- |Saudi Arabia |[[Riyadh]], [[Jeddah]] |February 3–6 |{{See also|Saudi Arabia–Turkey relations}} [[State visit]] {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |President Gül and his wife [[Hayrünnisa Gül]] made an official state visit to the Saudi Arabia at the invitation of [[King of Saudi Arabia|King]] [[Abdullah bin Abdulaziz]]. Mr. and Mrs. Gül were welcomed with an official ceremony at Riyadh [[King Khalid International Airport]] by Majesty [[Abdullah of Saudi Arabia|King Abdullah]]. After the ceremony, Gül attended the official dinner hosted by King Abdullah in his honour. On February 4, [[Abdullah Gül]] became the first foreign Muslim leader to address the [[Consultative Assembly of Saudi Arabia|Shura Council]].{{cite web|url=http://www.todayszaman.com/news-254174-turkey-and-saudi-arabia-the-buildup-to-syria-by-sultan-sooud-al-qassemi*.html|title=Turkey and Saudi Arabia: the buildup to Syria by Sultan Sooud Al Qassemi|publisher=[[Today's Zaman]]|date=2011-08-18|accessdate=2014-03-15}}{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49879/saudi-arabia.html|title=Foreign visits: Saudi Arabia|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=03-02-2009|accessdate=2014-03-15}} |} |- |Russia |[[Moscow]], [[Kazan]] |February 12–15 |{{See also|Russia–Turkey relations}} [[State visit]] {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |President Gül and First lady made an official state visit to the at the invitation of President [[Dmitry Medvedev]]. After the official welcoming ceremony, Gül held talks with his counterpart. Following the bilateral talks which they held a joint press conference at [[Grand Kremlin Palace]]. Also President Gül visited [[State Duma]] with [[Federation Council (Russia)|Federation Council]] and received Russian Prime Minister [[Vladimir Putin]]. On February 14 Abdullah Gül travelled [[Kazan]], the capital city of [[Tatarstan]] and met with [[Mintimer Shaimiev]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49882/rubia-federation.html|title=Foreign visits: Russia|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=12-02-2009|accessdate=2014-03-15}} |} |- |Kenya |[[Nairobi]] |February 20–22 |{{See also|Kenya–Turkey relations}} [[State visit]] {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |President Gül and his wife [[Hayrünnisa Gül]] made an official state visit to the Kenya. Gül is the first Turkish president to pay an official visit to Kenya. He met with Kenyan [[President of Kenya|President]] [[Mwai Kibaki]] and Prime Minister [[Raila Odinga]] and then visited to [[Nairobi National Park]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49885/kenya.html|title=Foreign visits: Kenya|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=2009-02-20|accessdate=2014-03-18}} |} |- |Tanzania |[[Dodoma]] |February 22–23 | [[State visit]] {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |President [[Abdullah Gül]] with his spouse paid an official visit to Tanzania at the invitation of Tanzanian [[President of Tanzania|President]] [[Jakaya Mrisho Kikwete]]. The two countries signed a protocol for technical, scientific, economic and commercial cooperation in agriculture. Also, President Gül's visit, the first official visit to Tanzania President level.{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/yurt-disi/254/49588/tanzanya.html|title=Foreign visits: Tanzania|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=2009-02-22|accessdate=2014-03-18}} |} |- |Iran |[[Tehran]] |March 10–11 |{{See also|Iran–Turkey relations}} {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |Abdullah Gül travalled to [[Tehran]] to attend the 10th summit meeting of the [[Economic Cooperation Organization]] (ECO). He during the visit, met with Iranian [[President of Iran|President]] [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]] and [[Supreme Leader of Iran|Supreme Leader]] [[Ali Khamenei]] and other participant leaders.{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49887/iran.html|title=Foreign visits: Iran|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=10-03-2009|accessdate=2014-03-18}} |} |- |Iraq |[[Baghdad]] |March 23–24 |{{See also|Iraq–Turkey relations}} [[State visit]] {| class="wikitable collapsible innercollapse" |- !Details |- |President Gül and his wife [[Hayrünnisa Gül]] made state visit to Iraq at the invitation of [[President of Iraq|President]] [[Jalal Talabani]]. Gül pair was welcomed with an official ceremony at the [[As-Salam Palace]]. President met with his counterpart Talabani and received Vice President [[Tariq Al-Hashimi]], Prime Minister [[Nouri al-Maliki]] and [[Iraqi Turkmen]] politician [[Saadeddin Arkej]]. Mr. Gül's talks during his Baghdad visit centred on bilateral relations as well as regional and global issues.{{cite web|url=http://www.tccb.gov.tr/foreign-visits/388/49888/iraq.html|title=Foreign visits: Irag|publisher=[[Çankaya Köşkü|Presidency of Republic of Turkey]]|date=2009-03-23|accessdate=2014-03-15}} |} |} ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{Foreign relations of Turkey}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gül Abdullah Presidential trips}} [[Category:Lists of diplomatic trips]] [[Category:Geography-related lists]] [[Category:21st century-related lists]] [[Category:Lists of diplomatic visits by heads of state]]

page.title: List of international presidential trips made by Aníbal Cavaco Silva
List of place names of Dutch origin

revision.comment: /* Straits */Added content
revision.text:
{{History of the Netherlands}} {{Expand list|date=July 2011}}
The [[Dutch people|Dutch]], aided by their skills in shipping, map making, finance and trade, traveled to every corner of the world and left their language embedded in names of places they visited. A fraction of these are still in use today.
To be included in this list, the place must have an article on Wikipedia or must have inline references showing the name is or was indeed Dutch.

revision.text:
{{See also|List of sovereign states|Lists by country|List of international rankings}} :''This list is [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Lists#Incomplete lists|incomplete]]. You can help by [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=List_of_terrorist_incidents&action=edit expanding it]''
This is a list of many '''lists of countries and territories''' by various definitions, including FIFA countries, federations, and fictional countries. A [[country]] or territory is a geographical area, either in the sense of ''[[nation]]'' (a cultural entity) or ''[[Sovereign state|state]]'' (a political entity).<ref>The [[Oxford English Dictionary]], Second Edition, with online updates as of September 2008. Entry "1. country"</ref>
* [[List of sovereign states|List of countries by name]]
==Demographics== {{see also|Demographics}} [[File:Menschentraube.jpg|thumb|right|[[Demographics]]]]

revision.comment: Disambiguated: [[ESRI]] → [[Environmental Systems Research Institute]]
revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=February 2016}}
'''Location intelligence''' ('''LI'''), or '''spatial intelligence''', is the process of deriving meaningful insight from [[geographic data and information|geospatial data]] relationships to solve a particular problem.<ref>Data Resources For Real Estate And Business Geography Analysis. Thrall,G.,I.,Ph.D.(2009)/Professor, Department of Geography, College of Liberal Arts And Sciences and Miller Center For Retail, College of Business, University of Florida</ref> It involves layering multiple data sets spatially and/or chronologically, for easy reference on a map, and its applications span industries, categories and organizations.
Maps have been used to represent information throughout the ages, but what might be referenced as the first example of true location 'intelligence' was in London in 1854 when [[John Snow]] was able to debunk theories about the spread of cholera by overlaying a map of the area with the location of water pumps and was able to narrow the source to a single water pump. This layering of information over a map was able to identify relationships between different sets of geospatial data.
Location or [[geographical information system]] (GIS) tools enable spatial experts to collect, store, [[data analysis|analyze]] and [[data visualization|visualize data]]. Location intelligence experts can use a variety of spatial and business analytical tools to measure optimal locations for operating a business or providing a service. Location intelligence experts begin with defining the [[business ecosystem]] which has many interconnected economic influences. Such economic influences include but are not limited to culture, lifestyle, labor, healthcare, cost of living, crime, economic climate and education.
==Further definitions== The term "location intelligence" is often used to describe the people, data and technology employed to geographically "map" information. These mapping applications can transform large amounts of data into color-coded visual representations that make it easy to see trends and generate meaningful intelligence. The creation of location intelligence is directed by [[domain knowledge]], formal frameworks, and a focus on decision support. Location cuts across through everything i.e. devices, platforms, software and apps, and is one of the most important ingredient of understanding context in sync with social data, mobile data, user data, sensor data.
Location intelligence is also used to describe the integration of a geographical component into [[business intelligence]] processes and tools, often incorporating [[spatial database]] and spatial [[OLAP]] tools.
In 2012, Wayne Gearey from the [[real estate industry]] ([[JLL (company)|JLL]]) offered the first applied course on location intelligence at the University of Texas at Dallas in which he defined location intelligence as the process for selecting the optimal location that will support workplace success and address a variety of business and financial objectives.<ref name="RealViews 2015">{{cite web|url=https://www.jllrealviews.com/trends/why-location-intelligence-is-a-game-changer-for-the-property-industry/|title=Why location intelligence is a ‘game changer’ for real estate|last=Avery|first=Lois|date=2015-05-20|website=RealViews|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161019164338/https://www.jllrealviews.com/trends/why-location-intelligence-is-a-game-changer-for-the-property-industry/|archive-date=2016-10-19|dead-url=yes|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=W.M. Gearey, N.M.Trodd, A. Fobes|title=Utilizing Location Intelligence for the Placement of Corporate Services|url=http://www.gla.ac.uk/media/media_401758_en.pdf}}</ref>
[[Pitney Bowes]] MapInfo Corporation describes location intelligence as follows: "Spatial information, commonly known as "Location", relates to involving, or having the nature of where. Spatial is not constrained to a geographic location however most common business uses of spatial information deal with how spatial information is tied to a location on the earth. Miriam-Webster® defines Intelligence as "The ability to learn or understand, or the ability to apply knowledge to manipulate one`s environment." Combining these terms alludes to how you achieve an understanding of the spatial aspect of information and apply it to achieve a significant competitive advantage."<ref>{{cite web |author=George Moon |publisher=Pitney Bowes |url=http://www.pbinsight.com/files/resource-library/resource-files/LocationIntell_WP_2-27Final.pdf |format=PDF |language=en |title=Location Intelligence – Meeting IT Expectation |date=c. 2008 |access-date=2015-10-05}}</ref>
Definition by [[Environmental Systems Research Institute|ESRI]] is as follows: "Location Intelligence is defined as the capacity to organize and understand complex data through the use of geographic relationships. LI organizes business and geographically referenced data to reveal the relationship of location to people, events, transactions, facilities, and assets."<ref>{{cite web |author=ESRI |url=https://www.esri.com/~/media/files/pdfs/library/whitepapers/pdfs/using-location-intelligence.pdf |format=PDF |language=en |title=Using Location Intelligence to Maximize the Value of BI |access-date=2015-10-05}}</ref>
Definition by [[Yankee Group]] within their White Paper "Location Intelligence in Retail Banking: "...a business management term that refers to spatial data visualization, contextualization and analytical capabilities applied to solve a business problem."<ref>{{cite web |author=Marcus Torchia |publisher=Pitney Bowes |url=http://www.pbinsight.com/files/resource-library/resource-files/yankee-group.pdf |format=PDF |language=en |title=Location Intelligence in Retail Banking |date=c. 2009 |access-date=2015-10-05}}</ref>
[[Near (company)|Near]] defines location intelligence as the gamut of geo-spatial analytic models, algorithms, techniques and tools that harness location-indexed streaming and static data to provide requisite answers to questions around location such as the attributes of i) a place, ii) people visiting a place, and iii) products consumed at a place. Location intelligence platforms encapsulate these technologies, ingest relevant data sources, and provide it as data-as-a-service, or use it to power data-driven products.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mmaglobal.com/articles/location-intelligence-next-frontier |title= Location Intelligence: The Next Frontier|publisher=Mobile Marketing Association, Inc|date=May 3, 2016}}</ref>
Instarea defines location intelligence as "Using [[machine learning]] algorithms to uncover trends that would be otherwise unknown using human based rules in a large location data set."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gartner.com/doc/3795764|title=Market Trends: Ways CSPs Can Exploit Location Data|last=|first=|date=|website=Gartner.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-24}}</ref>
==Commercial applications==
Location intelligence is used by a broad range of industries to improve overall business results. Applications include: * [[Communications]] and [[telecommunications]]: [[Network planning and design]], boundary identification, identifying new customer markets. * [[Financial services]]: Optimize branch locations, market analysis, [[Share of Wallet|share of wallet]] and [[cross-sell]] activities, [[mergers & acquisitions]], industry sector analysis, risk management. * [[Government]]: Census updates, law enforcement crime analysis, emergency response, environmental and land management, electoral [[redistricting]], tax jurisdiction assignment, [[urban planning]]. * [[Healthcare]]: Site selection, [[market segmentation]], network analysis, growth assessments. * [[Higher education]]: Student Recruitment, Alumni & Donor Tracking, Campus Mapping. * [[Hotel]]s and [[restaurant]]s: Customer profile analysis, site selection, [[target marketing]], expansion planning. * [[Insurance]]: Address validation, underwriting and [[risk management]], claims management, marketing and sales analysis, [[market penetration]] studies. * [[Mass media|Media]]: [[Target market]] identification, subscriber demographics, [[media planning]]. * [[Real estate]]: Site reports, comprehensive site analysis, retail modeling, presentation quality maps. * [[Retail]]: Site selection, maximize per-store sales, identify under-performing stores, market analysis. * [[Transportation]]: Transport planning, route monitoring. * [[K-12]] : School Site Selection, enrollment planning, school attendance area modification (boundary change), school consolidation, district consolidation, student achievement plotting.
== See also == * [[Geographic information system]] (GIS)
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Business intelligence]] [[Category:Market research]] [[Category:Strategic management]] [[Category:Geographic data and information]]

The '''NTv2''' ('''National Transformation version 2''') is a standard binary grid shift (.GSB) file format. It can transform coordinates between the [[NAD27]] and [[NAD83]] [[geodetic reference system]]s for example. The transformation is bidimensional (2D), or horizontal, and does not require heights.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://webapp.geod.nrcan.gc.ca/geod/tools-outils/ntv2.php|title= NTv2|website=Natural Resources Canada|accessdate=25 May 2018}}</ref><ref name=eye4software2018>{{cite web|url=https://www.eye4software.com/hydromagic/documentation/ntv2/|title= NTv2 National Transformation version 2|website=eye4software|accessdate=25 May 2018}}</ref>
==Development and adaptation==
The National Transformation format has been developed by [[Natural Resources Canada]]'s Geodetic Survey Division for conversions between [[NAD27]] and [[NAD83]] but it has been adapted to several other countries, such as [[Australia]], [[Belgium]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ngi.be/FR/FR2-1-7.shtm|title= Belgian Datum Lambert 2008/ETRS 89|website=NGI|accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref>, [[Brazil]], [[Canada]], [[France]], [[Germany]], [[New Zealand]], [[Portugal]], [[South Africa]], [[Spain]], [[Switzerland]], [[Venezuela]]<ref name=eye4software2018/> and the [[United Kingdom]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/business-and-government/help-and-support/navigation-technology/os-net/ostn02-ntv2-format.html|title= OSTN02 – NTv2 format|website=Ordnance Survey|accessdate=25 May 2018}}</ref>.
==References==

{{Cleanup|date=March 2010}} [[File:Upper Missouri River Breaks National Monument - Poster (13949391536).jpg|thumb|National Conservation Lands poster for Upper Missouri River Breaks National Monument (2014)]] '''National Conservation Lands''', formally known as the '''National Landscape Conservation System''', is a {{convert|35|e6acre|sing=on}} collection of lands in 873 federally recognized areas considered to be the crown jewels of the [[Western United States|American West]].<ref name=NCL>[https://www.blm.gov/programs/national-conservation-lands National Conservation Lands], [[Bureau of Land Management]]</ref> These lands represent 10% of the {{convert|258|e6acre}} managed by the [[Bureau of Land Management]] (BLM). The BLM is the largest federal public land manager and is responsible for over 40% of all the federal public land in the nation. The other major federal public land managers include the [[US Forest Service]] (USFS), [[National Park Service]] (NPS), and the [[US Fish and Wildlife Service]] (USFWS).
Over the years, the Bureau of Land Management has had to adjust its approach to public land management to fit the changing needs of the nation. The BLM historically has managed lands under its jurisdiction for extractive uses, such as mining, logging, grazing, and oil and gas production. In 1983, Congress acknowledged the value of watersheds, wildlife habitat, recreation, scenery, scientific exploration and other non-extractive uses with the designation of the first BLM-managed wilderness area—the Bear Trap Canyon unit of the Lee Metcalf Wilderness in Montana.<ref>wilderness.net</ref> In 1996, President Clinton underscored non-extractive priorities on BLM lands when he established the first national monument to be administered by the BLM—the Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument in southern Utah. With this and several similar designations, a new focus emerged that would become part of how the agency looks at the land it manages: the protection of special areas where conservation and restoration of the landscape and its biological or cultural resources is the overriding objective.
The Bureau of Land Management's National Landscape Conservation System, better known as the National Conservation Lands, was created in 2000 with the mission to "conserve, protect, and restore these nationally significant landscapes that have outstanding cultural, ecological, and scientific values for the benefit of current and future generations."<ref>[http://www.blm.gov/nlcs/ National Landscape Conservation System] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060215003855/http://www.blm.gov/nlcs/ |date=2006-02-15 }}, U.S. Bureau of Land Management accessed 5-12-15</ref>
There are ten different federal conservation designations for the units that make up the National Conservation Lands:
::* [[U.S. National Monument|National Monument]] ::* [[National Conservation Area]] ::* [[National Wilderness Preservation System|Wilderness Area]] ::* [[Wilderness Study Area]] ::* [[National Wild and Scenic Rivers|National Wild and Scenic River]] ::* [[National Scenic Trail]] ::* [[National Historic Trail]] ::* [[Cooperative Management and Protection Area]] ::* [[Forest reserve|Forest Reserve]] ::* [[Outstanding Natural Area]]
The Conservation System was created in 2000, but without Congressional authorization, there was no guarantee that the System would be permanent. The National Landscape Conservation System Act was signed into law in March 2009. The Act permanently unified the individual units as a public lands System, protecting the System in law so that it would no longer exist at the pleasure of each president. This marked the first new congressionally authorized public lands system in decades.
The Conservation System act was included in the Omnibus Public Land Management Act of 2009, which also added {{convert|1200000|acre}} of new designations to the System, including a National Monument, three National Conservation Areas, Wilderness, Wild and Scenic Rivers and National Scenic Trails.
== List of National Conservation Lands areas ==

{{Globalize|date=December 2010}} {| class="infobox bordered" style="width: 17em; text-align: left; font-size: 95%;" |+ style="font-size: larger;" | '''Notice to Mariners''' |- | colspan="2" style="text-align:center;" | [[Image:Notice-to-mariners-thumb.jpg|175px]]
The front cover of a Notice to Mariners. |- ! Purpose: | Provide corrections to navigational publications and nautical charts. |- ! Publication Frequency: | Weekly |- ! Published by: | [[National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency]] |- ! Available Online: | Yes [http://msi.nga.mil/NGAPortal/MSI.portal?_nfpb=true&_pageLabel=msi_portal_page_61] |- |} A '''notice to mariners''' (NTMWeb site uses abbreviation NTM) advises mariners of important matters affecting navigational safety, including new [[Hydrography|hydrographic information]], changes in [[channel (geography)|channel]]s and aids to [[navigation]], and other important data. Over 60 countries which produce nautical charts also produce a notice to mariners. About one third of these are weekly, another third are bi-monthly or monthly, and the rest irregularly issued according to need. For example, the [[United Kingdom Hydrographic Office]] issues weekly updates. ==United States== The U.S. ''Notice to Mariners'' is made available weekly by the [[National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency]] (NGA), prepared jointly with the [[National Ocean Service]] (NOS) and the [[U.S. Coast Guard]]. The information in the ''Notice to Mariners'' is formatted to simplify the correction of [[nautical chart|paper charts]], ''[[List of Lights]]'', ''[[Light List]]s'', ''[[United States Coast Pilots]]'', and other publications produced by NGA, NOS, and the U.S. Coast Guard. Information for the ''Notice to Mariners'' is contributed by: the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency (Department of Defense) for waters outside the territorial limits of the United States; National Ocean Service ([[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]], [[Department of Commerce]]), which is charged with surveying and charting the coasts and harbors of the United States and its territories; the U.S. Coast Guard ([[United States Department of Homeland Security|Department of Homeland Security]]) which is responsible for the safety of life at sea and the establishment and operation of aids to navigation; and the [[United States Army Corps of Engineers|Army Corps of Engineers]] ([[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]]), which is charged with the improvement of rivers and harbors of the United States. In addition, important contributions are made by foreign hydrographic offices and cooperating observers of all nationalities. The Notice consists of a page of Hydrograms listing important items in the Notice, a chart correction section organized by ascending chart number, a product catalog corrections section, a publications correction section, a summary of broadcast navigation warnings, and a page of additional miscellaneous information. It is the responsibility of users to decide which of their charts and publications require correction. Mariners are requested to cooperate in the correction of charts and publications by reporting all discrepancies between published information and conditions actually observed and by recommending appropriate improvements. A reporting form is provided in the back of each ''Notice to Mariners''. Issue No. 1 of each year contains important information on a variety of subjects which supplements information not usually found on charts and in navigational publications. This information is published as Special Notice to Mariners Paragraphs. Additional items considered of interest to the mariner are also included in this Notice. Much of the data in the U.S. ''Notice to Mariners'' is obtained from foreign notices. ==Canada== In Canada, the Canadian Coast Guard (CCG) [http://www.notmar.gc.ca/ Notice to Mariners] publication informs mariners of important navigational safety matters affecting Canadian Waters. This electronic publication is published on a monthly basis and can be downloaded from the [http://www.notmar.gc.ca/go.php?doc=eng/services/notmar/index Notices to Mariners (NOTMAR) Web site]. The information in the Notice to Mariners is formatted to simplify the correction of paper charts and navigational publications. The [http://www.notmar.gc.ca/ NOTMAR.gc.ca] site is a free 24/7 service providing mariners with up-to-date safety advisories. It provides mariners with a quick and easy to use interface to access Notices to Mariners information. This system also generates [http://www.notmar.gc.ca/search/mycharts-eng.php?czozMDoibnRtPXN0ZXBfb25lc3RhcnQmYWNjZXB0cHJpdj0xIjs= weekly and monthly notification mailers], for its registered users. These on-line mail services provides the [http://www.notmar.gc.ca/subscribe/ monthly Notices to Mariners publications] as well as the weekly(section II - chart corrections) notices that advise the mariner of the notices that have been issued against their chart selections. These mail services simplify the process for registered clients to update their publications and charts as required under the Canada Shipping Act. The NOTMAR web site also includes the [http://www.notmar.gc.ca/go.php?doc=eng/services/notmar/numindex historical Chart corrections] and [http://www.notmar.gc.ca/go.php?doc=eng/services/notmar/sec4index historical Sailing Direction corrections]; as well, it provides access to downloadable Chart Patches, contains links to CHS’s Chart Number 1, instructions for applying Notices to mariners to manually update their paper charts, and other useful information. ==Summary of Corrections== A close companion to the ''Notice to Mariners'' is the '''[http://msi.nga.mil/MSISiteContent/StaticFiles/SOCDownloadPage.htm Summary of Corrections]'''. The ''Summary'' is published in five volumes. Each volume covers a major portion of the earth including several chart regions and many subregions. Volume 5 also includes special charts and publications corrected by the ''Notice to Mariners''. Since the Summaries contain cumulative corrections, any chart, regardless of its print date, can be corrected with the proper volume of the Summary and all subsequent ''Notice to Mariners''. ==See also== *[[Notice to Airmen]] — [[aeronautical]] equivalent *[[American Practical Navigator]] *[[Buoy]] *[[Coast Pilots]] *[[Light List]] *[[List of Lights]] *[[Local Notice to Mariners]] *[[Sailing Directions]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Sources== The text of this article originated from sections 418 and 419 of The [[American Practical Navigator]], a document produced by the government of the [[United States|United States of America]]. ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20061016164246/http://www.irbs.com/bowditch/pdf/chapt04.pdf Chapter 4: Nautical Publications] - from the online edition of [[Nathaniel Bowditch]]'s ''American Practical Navigator'' * [http://msi.nga.mil/NGAPortal/MSI.portal?_nfpb=true&_pageLabel=msi_portal_page_61 Notice to Mariners Online] {{Navigation publications}} {{Works about sailing}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Notice To Mariners}} [[Category:Navigation]] [[Category:Hydrography]] [[Category:Sailing books]]

revision.text:
[[File:Clarke principal triangulation of Britain 1860.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.4|The principal triangulation mesh over Britain.]] The '''Principal Triangulation of Britain''' was the first high-precision [[trigonometry|trigonometric]] [[surveying|survey]] of the whole of Great Britain (including Ireland), carried out between 1791 and 1853 under the auspices of the [[Board of Ordnance]]. The aim of the survey was to establish precise geographical coordinates of almost 300 significant landmarks which could be used as the fixed points of local topographic surveys from which maps could be drawn. In addition there was a purely scientific aim in providing precise data for geodetic calculations such as the determination of the length of [[meridian arc]]s and the [[figure of the Earth]]. Such a survey had been proposed by [[William Roy]] (1726–1790) on his completion of the [[Anglo-French Survey (1784–1790)|Anglo-French Survey]] but it was only after his death that the [[Board of Ordnance]] initiated the trigonometric survey, motivated by military considerations in a time of a threatened French invasion. Most of the work was carried out under the direction of [[s:Dalby, Isaac (DNB00)|Isaac Dalby]], [[William Mudge]] and [[Thomas Frederick Colby]], but the final synthesis and report (1858) was the work of [[Alexander Ross Clarke]]. The survey stood the test of time for a century, until the [[Retriangulation of Great Britain]] between 1935 and 1962.
==History== In the aftermath of the [[Jacobite rising of 1745]] it was recognised that there was a need for an accurate map of the [[Scottish Highlands]] and the necessary survey was initiated in 1747 by Lieutenant-Colonel David Watson, a Deputy Quartermaster-General of the [[Board of Ordnance]]. Watson employed William Roy as a civilian assistant to carry out the bulk of the work. Subsequently, Roy, having enlisted in the army and having become a very competent surveyor, proposed (1763) a national survey which would be a plan for defence at a time when French invasions were threatened. The proposal was rejected on grounds of expense.<ref>The early history of the Ordnance Survey is covered in {{harvtxt|Owen|Pilbeam|1992}} pp 3–14(true), 12–24(pdf), and {{harvtxt|Seymour|1980}} pp. 1–20 (true), 15–35(pdf).</ref>
Roy continued to lobby for a survey and his ambitions were realised to a certain extent by an unexpected development. In 1783 the [[French Academy of Sciences]] claimed that the latitude and longitude differences between the [[Royal Observatory, Greenwich]] and the [[Paris Observatory]] were incorrect, and it was proposed (to the [[Royal Society]]) that the differences could be reconciled by high precision triangulation over the intervening terrain.<ref>{{harvnb|Knowles|2003}}.</ref> The Royal Society agreed and, jointly with the Board of Ordnance, they invited Roy to oversee the project. (Main article; [[Anglo-French Survey (1784–1790)]].)
Roy's first task (1784) was to measure a base line between [[Hampton, London|Hampton]] Poor House and King's Arbour on [[Hounslow Heath]], a distance of just over 5 miles (8 km).<ref>A full account of the measurement of the Hounslow Heath baseline is given in {{harvtxt|Roy|1785}}. The appendix includes detailed maps and figures.</ref> This was a painstaking process: three rods of about 20 ft. were supported on trestles and the ends aligned to an accuracy of a thousandth part of an inch. The first rod was then carried to the end of the third, an operation to be repeated 1370 times. The final measurement gave the length of the base as 27404.01 ft. (8352 metres).
[[File:RamsdenRS theodolite of 1787.jpg|thumb|upright|The first Ramsden theodolite as used by Roy. (Destroyed by war damage in 1941.)]] For the subsequent triangulation<ref>The strategy of the triangulation is outlined in {{harvtxt|Roy|1787}}. The appendix includes detailed maps and figures.</ref> Roy ordered a new [[theodolite]] from leading instrument-maker [[Jesse Ramsden]]. This [[Ramsden theodolite]], delivered in 1787, for the first time divided angular scales accurately to within a [[arcsecond|second of arc]].<ref>A full description of the first Ramsden theodolite is given in {{harvtxt|Roy|1790}}. The appendix includes detailed figures.</ref><ref>The theodolite constructed for Roy by Ramsden is called the Royal Society theodolite. See {{harvnb|Insley|2008}} ''The Great Theodolites''</ref> The theodolite was the largest ever constructed but, despite its massive size, it was carried from London to the Channel coast and employed on hills, steeples and a moveable tower. At each location the angles to other vertices of the triangulation mesh were measured many times, often at night time using newly devised lights. Finally the angle data was used to calculate the sides of the triangles by using [[spherical trigonometry]].<ref>Roy's final report, which was put through the press by Isaac Dalby, is {{harvtxt|Roy|1790}}.</ref>
[[File:3foottheodoliteramsden.jpg|thumb|upright|The second Ramsden theodolite as purchased by the Board Ordnance. Now in the [[Science Museum, London]]]] The final results were inconclusive, for triangulation was inferior to the precision of astronomical measurements, but the survey paved the way for all future work in terms of high precision measurements of length and angle, together with the techniques of calculating on an ellipsoidal surface. In his final report, published posthumously, Roy once again pressed for the extension of the survey to the rest of Britain. His successors would oblige. As Master of the Board of Ordnance (from 1782), Charles Lennox, 3rd Duke of Richmond, viewed Roy's work with great interest, At the same time he was acutely aware that Britain, lacking a national survey, was falling behind the standards of many other European countries. Moreover, the renewed threat of French invasion made him alarmed at the lack of accurate maps, particularly of the southern counties. The catalyst for action was the sudden availability of a new improved Ramsden theodolite<ref>The Ramsden theodolite purchase by Richmond is referred to as The Board of Ordnance theodolite. See {{harvnb|Insley|2008}} ''The Great Theodolites''</ref> which had been intended for the [[East India Company]]. The purchase of this instrument on 21 June 1791 by the Board is taken as the inauguration of the [[Ordnance Survey]].<ref>An official [https://www.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/blog/2016/06/celebrating-225-years-with-a-map/ OS blog] celebrating 225 years of British mapping.</ref> The very next day Richmond appointed [[s:Dalby, Isaac (DNB00)|Isaac Dalby]] as its first employee, with a brief to extend Roy's survey.<ref>Dalby was a civilian mathematician who had assisted Roy from 1787. See {{harvtxt|Owen|Pilbeam|1992}} p11(true), 21(pdf), and {{harvtxt|Seymour|1980}} p22(true),36(pdf).</ref> In the following month Richmond appointed [[William Mudge]] and Edward Williams, the latter as the first superintendent of the survey.
<!--The baseline derived during that work, together with the new theodolite, served as the basis for the planning and execution of the subsequent work on the Principal Triangulation. Around 1791, shortly after his death, Roy's team began the field work, using the specially built Ramsden theodolite. In 1794 a seven-mile-long baseline of verification was measured on [[Salisbury Plain]].
Eventually the triangulation extended to cover the whole of the British Isles, after it was decided in 1824 that a 6-inch-to-the-mile (1:10,560) [[map]] of [[Ireland]] was necessary for accurate land taxing. -->
==Re-measurement of the Hounslow baseline== [[File:General Roys Baseline.jpg|right|thumb|General Roy's baseline: map as about 1935]] For the 1784 measurement of the original base-line across Hounslow Heath, Roy had ordered three deal rods cut from a new mast in the Admiralty dock yards. These were intended to be used for the precision measurement but Roy also ordered a 100 ft steel chain from Ramsden which could be used for a quick preliminary measurement.<ref>{{harvtxt|Roy|1785}} Section I</ref> The deal rods proved ineffective because of their changes with humidity and they were replaced with glass rods for the final measurement; however Roy observed that the chain itself was just as accurate as the rods. For this reason the 1791 survey started by remeasuring the base with two new 100 ft chains, the second to be kept unused as a reference against which any stretching of the first would be detected.
The process of measurement was exceedingly precise.<ref>{{harvtxt|Mudge|1794}}</ref> Since the ground was undulating and falling about 370 ft. along the length of the base, the measurement was carried out over 26 stages with varying slopes, the chains for any one stage being constrained to a perfectly straight line by many intermediate supports. These hypotenuse measurements were then projected to the horizontal. Furthermore, the temperature varied from day to day and each measurement was corrected to the length that a chain would take at 62 °F. Finally, the length of the base was reduced to its projection at sea level using the height of the south base above the Thames and the fall in the Thames down to its estuary. The final result was approximately 3 inches less than that of Roy and the mean value of 27404.2 ft. was taken of the baseline. The difference of the two values meant that the accuracy of the measurement could be claimed to be 1 inch in 27,404 ft, which is 3 parts per million.
==Corrections== During subsequent triangulation, errors due to atmospheric refraction, deflection of plumb-bobs, temperature, and the spherical nature of the earth (meaning there were [[Spherical geometry|more than 180 degrees in a triangle]]) were all allowed for.
==See also== {{Portal|Atlas}} * [[Ordnance Survey]] * [[Ordnance Survey Drawings]] * [[Great Trigonometric Survey|Great Trigonometric Survey of India]]
==References==
{{reflist}}
==Bibliography== *Royal Engineers. Their [http://www.army.mod.uk/royalengineers/26315.aspx present website] has a small history section. The [https://web.archive.org/web/20060829135946/http://www.remuseum.org.uk/rem_his_history.htm previous website] (at [https://archive.org/web/ archive.org]) had more information including a [https://web.archive.org/web/20060829140407/http://www.remuseum.org.uk/biography/rem_bio_roy.htm biography of Roy]. The archived website gives general background information on the Royal Engineers during the time of Roy. * Rachel Hewitt (2010), ''Map of a Nation'', London: Granta Books. {{ISBN|978-1-84708-254-1}} *{{cite book |ref= harv |year=1858b |first=Alexander Ross |last=Clarke |first2=Henry |last2=James |authorlink=Alexander Ross Clarke |authorlink2=Henry James (British Army officer) |title=Account of the observations and calculations of the Principal Triangulation; and of the figure, dimensions and mean specific gravity of the Earth as derived therefrom. |publisher=G.E. Eyre and W. Spottiswoode |location=London |url=http://google.co.uk/books?id=H2gD6s3n8ZgC |oclc=757179661 |postscript = . [http://google.co.uk/books?id=pHTlAAAAMAAJ PLATES]. An excellent summary of the report was published in the [http://articles.adsabs.harvard.edu/full/1859MNRAS..19..194C Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]. }} *{{cite conference |ref=harv |title=The Tale of the Great Theodolites |first=Jane |last=Insley |year =2008 |conference=[http://www.fig.net/ FIG] Working Week on ''Integrating the Generations''. |location= Sweden |url=http://www.fig.net/pub/fig2008/papers/hs03/hs03_01_insley_2838.pdf }} *{{cite journal |ref=harv |title=The French Connexion – Between English and French Map Surveys |last=Knowles |first=Michael |year =2003 |journal=Proceedings of the Bath Royal Literary and Scientific Institution (BRLSI) |volume=7 |postscript=.[https://web.archive.org/web/20071018222953/http://www.brlsi.org/proceedvol7/Astronomy200301.htm Available online] }} *{{cite journal |ref = {{harvid|Mudge1}} |year = 1794 |last = Mudge Pilkington White, [http://gdl.cdlr.strath.ac.uk/smcj/smcj011/smcj0111001.htm The Ordnance Survey Of The United Kingdom], Scottish Mountaineering Club Journal Volume 2 Number 5

revision.comment: Undid revision 846883792 by [[Special:Contributions/39.43.226.52|39.43.226.52]] ([[User talk:39.43.226.52|talk]])
revision.text:
[[File:Ancient lights signs Clerkenwell.JPG|thumb|Ancient Lights signs in [[Clerkenwell]], [[London]], [[England]]]]
'''Right to light''' is a form of [[easement]] in [[English law]] that gives a long-standing owner of a building with windows a right to maintain the level of [[illumination (lighting)|illumination]]. It is based on the '''Ancient Lights''' law.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fpkDAAAAQAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=%22Ancient+lights+%22&as_brr=3&client=firefox-a&cd=1#v=onepage&q=&f=false |title=On ancient lights: and the evidence ... - Google Books |publisher=books.google.co.uk |accessdate=2010-02-23 }}</ref> The rights are most usually acquired under the [[Prescription Act 1832]].
==Rights== In effect, the owner of a building with windows that have received natural daylight for 20 years or more is entitled to forbid any construction or other obstruction that would deprive him or her of that illumination. Neighbours cannot build anything that would block the light without permission. The owner may build more or larger windows but cannot enlarge their new windows before the new period of 20 years has expired. It is also possible for a right to light to exist if granted expressly by [[deed]], or granted implicitly, for example under the rule in ''[[Wheeldon v Burrows|Wheeldon v. Burrows]]'' (1879).
Once a right to light exists, the owner of the right is entitled to "sufficient light according to the ordinary notions of mankind": ''[[Colls v. Home & Colonial Stores Ltd]]'' (1904). Courts rely on [[expert witnesses]] to define this term. Since the 1920s, experts have used a method proposed by [[Percy Waldram]] to assist them with this. Waldram suggested that ordinary people require one [[foot-candle]] of [[illuminance]] (approximately ten [[lux]]) for reading and other work involving visual discrimination. This equates to a [[sky factor]] (similar to the [[daylight factor]]) of 0.2%. Today, Waldram's methods are increasingly subject to criticism<ref>[http://www.emeraldinsight.com/Insight/viewContentItem.do;jsessionid=D62CF262C987771E9EA2A8DB73A9A48F?contentType=Article&contentId=1603352 Was Waldram wrong?], P Defoe, ''[[Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors]]'', 19 October 2006</ref><ref>Michael Pitts (2000), [http://www.emeraldinsight.com/Insight/viewContentItem.do?contentType=Article&hdAction=lnkpdf&contentId=844738 The grumble point: is it still worth the candle?], ''[[Structural Survey]]'' '''18'''(5):255–8</ref> and the future of expert evidence in rights to light cases is currently the subject of much debate within the surveying profession.<ref>[http://www.rics.org/Practiceareas/Property/Rightstolight/Rights%20to%20light%20the%20debate.html Rights to light surveying practice, the debate begins], Paul Chynoweth, ''[[Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors]]'', 21 September 2006</ref>
After the [[Second World War]], owners of buildings could gain new rights by registering properties that had been destroyed in [[bombing]]s and the period was temporarily increased to 27 years.
In the centre of [[London]] near [[Chinatown, London|Chinatown]] and [[Covent Garden]], particularly in back alleyways, signs saying "Ancient Lights" can be seen marking individual windows. The design and construction of [[Broadcasting House]] in the early 1930s was also affected by locals declaring their right to ancient lights. It resulted in a unique asymmetrical sloped design that allowed for sunlight to pass over the building to the residential quarters eastwards, long since demolished and now home to the new Egton Wing.
Recent case law from 2010, relating to a commercial development in the centre of Leeds ([http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWHC/Ch/2010/2245.html ''HKRUK II v Heaney'']) has significantly changed the perceptions of risk associated with right-to-light, particularly in the context of commercial schemes. This case upheld an injunction against a commercial property. The result of this is that many developers are now looking to work with local authorities to try to use section 237 of the [[Town and Country Planning Act 1990]]. This potentially stops injunctions against schemes that have over-riding social or economic advantages to an area.
=== United States === Under [[United States tort law]], in ''[[Fontainebleau Hotel]] Corp. v. Forty-Five Twenty-Five, Inc.'' (1959) the Florida [[Appellate Court]] stated that the "ancient lights" doctrine had been unanimously repudiated in the United States.<ref>[http://www.american.edu/dgolash/fontainebleau%20v.%204525.htm FOUNTAINEBLEAU HOTEL CORP., a Florida corporation, and Charnofree Corporation, a Florida corporation, Appellants, v. FORTY-FIVE TWENTY-FIVE, INC., a Florida corporation, Appellee.] @ LexisNexis Academic</ref><ref>[http://home.uchicago.edu/~rmcnary/briefs/property/Fontainebleau/ Case @ University of Chicago] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080421194453/http://home.uchicago.edu/~rmcnary/briefs/property/Fontainebleau/ |date=2008-04-21 }}</ref>
In 1984, voters in [[San Francisco]] passed Proposition K, which prevents construction of any building over 40 feet that casts a shadow on a public park, unless the Planning Commission decides the shadow is insignificant. This proposition causes problems for [[Oceanwide_Center,_San_Francisco|a proposed 34-story building south of Market Street]], which would cast a shadow on a public park ten blocks away, for one hour of the day in the fall, as well as St. Mary's Square, Justin Herman Plaza, and Union Square for significant parts of the year.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dineen|first1=J.K.|title=Long shadows create political hurdle for S.F. skyscraper project|url=http://www.sfchronicle.com/bayarea/article/Long-shadows-create-political-hurdle-for-S-F-7382467.php|accessdate=30 June 2017|publisher=SF Chronicle|date=April 28, 2016}}</ref> [[Massachusetts]] has similar laws against the casting of shadows on [[Boston Common]], the [[Public_Garden_(Boston)|Public Garden]], and other important public open spaces.<ref>http://archives.lib.state.ma.us/actsResolves/1990/1990acts0362.pdf</ref>
== See also == {{wiktionary|ancient lights}} * [[Daylighting]] * [[Protected view]] * [[Air rights]] * [[Spite fence]] * [[Spite house]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== Further reading == {{EB1911 poster|Ancient Lights}} * [http://www.palgrave-journals.com/jba/journal/v4/n1/full/jba200818a.html Andrew Francis, ''Right of light ahead!'', Journal of Building Appraisal, (2008) 4, 5–13] * Paul Chynoweth (2004) [http://www.lawlectures.co.uk/RTL-1.pdf Progressing the rights to light debate – Part 1: a review of current practice, Structural Survey, Vol. 22, No. 3, pp. 131–7] * [http://www.ricsbooks.com/productInfo.asp?product_id=8470 ''Anstey's Rights of Light''], John Anstey and Lance Harris, {{ISBN|978-1-84219-222-1}} * [http://www.ricsbooks.com/productInfo.asp?product_id=11554 ''Rights of Light''], Stephen Bickford-Smith and Andrew Francis, {{ISBN|978-1-84661-024-0}} * [http://www.ricsbooks.com/productInfo.asp?product_id=9041 "Practical Neighbour Law Handbook"] Alistair Redler, {{ISBN|978-1-84219-236-8}} Davis, Howard. "The Future of Ancient Lights," Journal of Architectural and Planning Research, Vol. 6, No. 2, Summer 1989, pp. 132-153.
{{Authority control}}
